Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle in hand, watching a group of teenagers laughing and daring each other to dive from the shallow end. As a lifeguard, I was expected to enforce the no-diving rule, to keep everyone safe, even if it meant being the “bad guy.” My supervisor had reminded me just this morning: “No exceptions, no matter who it is.” But as a citizen, I also felt the weight of other responsibilities. My tax documents were finally organized, and I’d planned to help at the free vaccine clinic this weekend—something I believed was important for our community’s health. The thought of missing the clinic gnawed at me, but right now, the immediate safety of these kids was in my hands. I could already hear their protests if I called them out, and I worried about being seen as overbearing. My mind raced, torn between the duty to enforce the rules and my desire to be a supportive, contributing member of the community. I hesitated, heart pounding, caught between the expectations of my two roles.
